title: 105_hr864
content: The Act may be cited as the "Marian Anderson Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". Marian Anderson, a renowned singer and civil rights champion, was born in Philadelphia in 1897. She played a crucial role in promoting African-American musicians in classical music. Throughout her life, she received numerous prestigious awards, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, a special gold medal from Congress, the U.N. Peace Prize, and the National Arts Medal. In 1986, Marian Anderson received the National Arts Medal, and in 1997, her centennial birth anniversary will be celebrated. In 1986, Marian Anderson received the National Arts Medal, and in 1997, her centennial birth anniversary will be celebrated. TITLE I--COMMEMORATIVE COINS SEC. 101. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. In commemoration of Marian Anderson's centennial birth, the Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 coins and half dollar coins with specific weights, diameters, and silver-copper composition. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. All coins minted under this title shall be considered numismatic items. The Secretary must obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins is specified in this section. The design of the coins minted under this title shall be emblematic of Marian Anderson's accomplishments, with inscriptions of value, years, and various words. A design competition will be held for the obverse of the coin. The design for the coins minted under this title will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 104. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this title will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary can start issuing these coins after the enactment of this Act, but minting authority will end on July 31, 1998. The coins issued under this title will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a surcharge. Sales of coins minted under this title will include a surcharge of $14 per $1 coin and $7 per half dollar coin. SEC. 106. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this title, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 107. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The Secretary shall promptly pay the first $2,000,000 of surcharges from coin sales under this title as follows: 50% to the Smithsonian Institution for African-American art, history, and culture exhibits, and 50% to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for educational programs. Any excess surcharges will be paid to the National Museum of American. The remaining surcharges from coin sales will be paid to the National Museum of American History in Washington, D.C. for the support of the National Numismatic Collection. Organizations receiving payments will be audited as per section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 108. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for minting and issuing coins. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee of full payment from a depository institution. TITLE II--CIRCULATING COINS SEC. 201. AUTHORITY TO REDESIGN HALF DOLLAR CIRCULATING COINS. The Secretary has the authority to redesign half dollar circulating coins to bear the same design as commemorative coins minted under the Marian Anderson Centennial Commemorative Coin Act.
